awd_titl_txt: Big Astronomy in Chile through Dome+
awd_abstract_narration:
As part of its overall strategy to enhance learning in informal environments, the Advancing Informal STEM Learning (AISL) program seeks to advance new approaches to, and evidence-based understanding of, the design and development of STEM learning in informal environments. This includes providing multiple pathways for broadening access to and engagement in STEM learning experiences, advancing innovative research on and assessment of STEM learning in informal environments, and developing understandings of deeper learning by participants.  The team of Associated Universities Inc. (AUI), Michigan State University (MSU), California Academy of Science (the Academy), Astronomical Society of the Pacific (ASP), and Association of Universities for Research in Astronomy (AURA), will bring together experts in astronomy, STEM education, and planetarium show production. This work will tell the story of the people and places that make "big astronomy" possible, particularly the search for exoplanets and understanding of how planets form. The show and related materials will be presented in dozens of venues around the USA and internationally. Through a planetarium show and learning experiences that extend beyond the theater, the team will take visitors to extreme sites of the NSF ground-based observatories on the mountains of Chile and meet the diverse people who enable amazing discoveries in astronomy. In addition, the project develops the Dome+ model, which ensures engagement does not end with the planetarium. Dome+ will include additional content, weekly virtual sessions with STEM professionals, and a suite of closely linked outreach activities.

Dome+ will serve as a model to extend engagement and increase the impact of future planetarium shows. Project goals include 1) increasing awareness of the research in astronomy being made at the NSF-funded observatories in Chile, 2) increasing awareness and interest in diverse STEM career opportunities at large observatories and related institutions in the USA, 3) increasing knowledge of science enabled by big observatories, 4) increasing Latinx perceptions as someone who can have a career at a major observatory, and 5) developing the Dome+ model and identify best practices for implementation.  Iterative and summative evaluation of the project by collaborators at MSU will address four main questions: How does the Dome+ model affect visitors' perceptions of diversity of careers in STEM? How does the Dome+ model affect visitors' interest and understanding of Chile as an ideal observing location for astronomy? How does the Dome+ model support visitors' interest and understanding of the science of exoplanets? How do planetariums implement Dome+, and how does implementation affect the outcomes for visitors?  The impact assessment component of this project takes places in four phases. The goals of the first phase are to leverage the expertise of the research team to inform the creation of the planetarium show and to set up a robust research agenda to be achieved in Years 2-4 of the project. The goals of the second phase are to collect preliminary data from visitors on their responses to planetarium show content and to use this information to advise on edits to the show and to develop the content and format of the web-portal and educational materials. The goal of the third phase is to then collect data on how effectively the technology-rich environments of the three components of the Dome+ model (planetarium show, web-portal, educational materials) work in concert to reach the intended goals of changing visitors' perceptions of diversity in STEM, engaging visitors with astronomy content on exoplanets, and exposing visitors to the wonders of astronomy research in Chile. The goal of the fourth phase is to perform data analysis, synthesize findings and make recommendations for future implementations of the Dome+ model for practitioners.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Big Astronomy in Chile through Dome+ project, funded by the National Science Foundation (NSF), brought together astronomy and STEM education experts to develop a bilingual planetarium show and accompanying resources that highlight the NSF-funded observatories in Chile and the diverse teams behind groundbreaking discoveries. The project's research examined how planetarium programming engages diverse audiences and builds STEM identity, with a focus on accessibility for Deaf and Hard of Hearing (DHH) audiences and the effectiveness of virtual versus in-person learning experiences.

Project goals included:

  • Increase awareness of the investments in astronomy being made by the US in Chile and why those investments are being made,

  • Increase awareness and interest in diverse STEM career opportunities at large observatories,

  • Increase knowledge of science enabled by Large Observatories,

  • Increase Latinx perceptions as someone who can have a career at a major observatory, and

  • Develop the Dome+ model and identify best practices for implementation.

Intellectual Merit
The project advanced understanding of how planetarium programming engages diverse audiences, using the Dome+ model, which integrates shows with extended learning experiences. Research examined the social and educational dynamics of planetarium audiences including accessibility practices like captioning. These studies identified opportunities to enhance inclusivity in dome theaters and revealed distinct engagement patterns between virtual and in-person audiences, offering guidance to tailor programming across informal learning settings.

Broader Impacts
The planetarium show, Big Astronomy: People, Places, Discoveries, was produced in both English and Spanish and has been shared with over 330 planetariums across 35 countries, with a reported estimated audience reach of over 8 million. Two iterations of a total of 345 educational toolkits, one designed for Blind and Low Vision (BLV) audiences specifically, were distributed to astronomy clubs and museums,with 40 organizations reporting on 91 events reaching over 15,000 people (actual numbers estimated to be 3-4x higher). Online resources, including a website, social media presence, and a YouTube channel, have extended reach to tens of thousands more and ensure ongoing engagement of Big Astronomy products.

Key Outcomes
The Big Astronomy resources were widely disseminated in a variety of settings with the show in all of its formats receiving a total of 1,323 downloads across 71 countries, by groups including public schools, private schools, planetariums, museums, libraries, amateur astronomy clubs, and homeschools. The show was adapted into flat screen and 360 degree formats and translated into three additional languages. The show also includes closed captioning and an audio track. Additionally, astronomy clubs and museums utilized Big Astronomy toolkit in both in-person and virtual settings. The project published and shared findings from 7 research papers. The legacy-state website continues to host all associated resources. 

In the face of the COVID-19 pandemic, the Big Astronomy project pivoted its focus to engage audiences through virtual platforms and innovative programming. As in-person planetarium visits were disrupted, the project expanded its online presence, hosting 52 live social media events and streaming the planetarium show to global audiences. These virtual efforts reached over 28,000 viewers and provided a connection to STEM education during a time of isolation. Additionally, a 360-degree Streaming Kit was developed to help planetariums offer immersive experiences online.

As pandemic restrictions eased, Big Astronomy launched a targeted promotional campaign culminating in Community Day events throughout April 2023. These events encouraged organizations worldwide to showcase the planetarium show and utilize its educational resources, resulting in 274 new downloads of the film. With an estimated reach of over 85,000 viewers and 3,600 direct participants, Community Day highlighted the ability of the project to mobilize a global network of educators, planetarians, and amateur astronomers. 

In 2022, Big Astronomy secured supplemental funding from NSF to enhance its focus on accessibility and inclusion, particularly for BLV and DHH communities. Audio description tracks for the planetarium show and tactile versions of educational materials tailored for BLV audiences were developed and research on captioning options in planetariums were conducted and shared. These resources and studies expanded the reach of Big Astronomy and established best practices for making informal science education more accessible.

A modular Big Astronomy workshop framework was developed to enable continued distribution of Big Astronomy products beyond project timeline and successfully engaged over 55 educators through pilot workshops at major conferences. These workshops provided participants with inclusive teaching strategies and tools and provided them with BLV toolkits. Feedback from participants pointed to the framework's strengths as a professional development resource, particularly in its adaptability and practicality. 

To ensure sustainable and long-term impact of Big Astronomy, the International Astronomical Union's North American Regional Office of Astronomy for Development (NA-ROAD) will continue to distribute the project's resources. Professional networks such as the International Planetarium Society, the Great Lakes Planetarium Association, and the Astronomical Society of the Pacific will further disseminate the workshop framework and educational materials, extending the project's reach beyond the grant period.
